item.title: Photo highlights of the day
item.trailText: Graduate fashion in London, a sunken cruise ship in China, and airborne photobombers in Rome
item.standFirst: The Guardian’s picture editors bring you a selection of the best photographs from around the world, including graduate fashion in London, a sunken cruise ship in China, and airborne photobombers in Rome

displayImages.caption: London, UK A model wears an eye-catching design by Niamh Maguire, from the Manchester School of Art, on day three of graduate fashion week, at The Old Truman Brewery in Brick Lane, east London Photograph: John Phillips/WireImage
displayImages.altText: London, UK Designs by Niamh Maguire from Manchester School of Art on day 3 of Graduate Fashion Week at The Old Truman Brewery
displayImages.cleanCaption: London, UK A model wears an eye-catching design by Niamh Maguire, from the Manchester School of Art, on day three of graduate fashion week, at The Old Truman Brewery in Brick Lane, east London

displayImages.caption: Java, Indonesia A towering Buddha statue stands in the middle of a busy shopping centre in Surabaya to mark the spiritual leader’s birthday Photograph: Juni Kriswanto/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Java, Indonesia A huge effigy of Buddha is installed at a shopping mall in Surabaya for devotees and shoppers to give prayers marking Buddha’s birthday
displayImages.cleanCaption: Java, Indonesia A towering Buddha statue stands in the middle of a busy shopping centre in Surabaya to mark the spiritual leader’s birthday

displayImages.caption: Jianli, China Rescuers pull a survivor from an overturned cruise ship in the Yangtze river in Hubei. The Dongfangzhixing, or Eastern Star, was carrying 458 passengers when it was caught in a cyclone and capsized Photograph: Ding Lin/Xinhua Press/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Jianli, China Rescuers drag a survivor out of water from the overturned passenger ship in the Yangtze River in Hubei Province. The ship, named Dongfangzhixing, or Eastern Star, sank late Monday carrying 405 passenger after being caught in a cyclone
displayImages.cleanCaption: Jianli, China Rescuers pull a survivor from an overturned cruise ship in the Yangtze river in Hubei. The Dongfangzhixing, or Eastern Star, was carrying 458 passengers when it was caught in a cyclone and capsized

displayImages.caption: Jianli, China Rescue teams work close to the sunken ship as night falls. See more pictures here Photograph: Kim Kyung-Hoon/Reuters
displayImages.altText: A rescue ship and workers are seen around sunken ship as night falls
displayImages.cleanCaption: Jianli, China Rescue teams work close to the sunken ship as night falls. See more pictures here

displayImages.caption: Mumbai, India Married Hindu women perform rituals around a banyan tree for the Vat Savitri celebration. Female devotees will pray and fast throughout the day for the prosperity and longevity of their husbands Photograph: Divyakant Solanki/EPA
displayImages.altText: Mumbai, India Hindu married women perform rituals around a Banyan tree on the holy occasion of the Vat Savitri festival
displayImages.cleanCaption: Mumbai, India Married Hindu women perform rituals around a banyan tree for the Vat Savitri celebration. Female devotees will pray and fast throughout the day for the prosperity and longevity of their husbands

displayImages.caption: Rome, Italy A trio of birds photobomb a performance by the Frecce Tricolori military aeronautical team during Republic Day celebrations Photograph: Angelo Carconi/EPA
displayImages.altText: Rome, Italy A trio of birds photobomb’a performance by the military aeronautical team Frecce Tricolori during celebrations marking republic day
displayImages.cleanCaption: Rome, Italy A trio of birds photobomb a performance by the Frecce Tricolori military aeronautical team during Republic Day celebrations

displayImages.altText: Scotland, UK The Jacobite steam train crosses the river Lochy as it departs Fort William
displayImages.cleanCaption: Scotland, UK A Jacobite steam train crosses the river Lochy as it departs Fort William

displayImages.caption: Moscow, Russia A goldsmith beetle crawls over stone-breaker flowers in a garden outside the city centre Photograph: Yuri Kadobnov/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Moscow, Russia A goldsmith beetle (cetonia aurata) crawls over stone-breaker (saxifraga) flowers in a garden outside the city centre
displayImages.cleanCaption: Moscow, Russia A goldsmith beetle crawls over stone-breaker flowers in a garden outside the city centre

displayImages.caption: Cairo, Egypt Ousted president Mohamed Morsi gestures from the defendants cage as he attends his trial at the police academy on the outskirts of the capital. An Egyptian court postponed its final ruling on Morsi, who was sentenced to death along with dozens of others over a mass jailbreak during the 2011 uprising Photograph: Khaled Desouki/AFP/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Cairo, Egypt Ousted Egyptian president Mohamed Morsi gestures from the defendants cage as he attends his trial at the police academy on the outskirts of the capital. displayImages.cleanCaption: Bengaluru, India A cow stands in the middle of a busy road as auto-rickshaws whizz by

displayImages.caption: Masada, Israel Performers walk to the stage for a dress rehearsal of Giacomo Puccini’s Tosca before the Israeli opera festival at the Unesco world heritage site. Masada was at the centre of a Roman siege that ended in AD73 when hundreds of Jewish people killed themselves rather than be slaves to the Romans Photograph: Nir Elias/Reuters

item.title: Photo highlights of the day
item.trailText: International Children’s Day, preparations for the Baku Games, the Havana biennial, and a lip-smacking surprise for James Corden in Beverly Hills
item.standFirst: The Guardian’s picture editors bring you a selection of the best photographs from around the world including International Children’s Day, preparations for the Baku Games, the Havana biennial, and a lip-smacking surprise for James Corden in Beverly Hills

displayImages.caption: Beijing, China Luisa, an eye-catching six-year-old poodle, goes for a stroll Photograph: Kim Kyung-Hoon/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Beijing, China A six-year-old female poodle named Luisa who has dyed fur, walks with her owner
displayImages.cleanCaption: Beijing, China Luisa, an eye-catching six-year-old poodle, goes for a stroll

displayImages.caption: Paris, France Municipal workers remove barriers laden with padlocks on the Pont des Arts. The accumulation of the so-called love locks, a popular phenomenon in many European cities where couples attach a lock to the side of bridges to symbolise their love, posed a safety problem because of their weight Photograph: Chesnot/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: Paris, France Municipal workers remove the barriers with love padlocks on the Pont des Arts
displayImages.cleanCaption: Paris, France Municipal workers remove barriers laden with padlocks on the Pont des Arts. The accumulation of the so-called love locks, a popular phenomenon in many European cities where couples attach a lock to the side of bridges to symbolise their love, posed a safety problem because of their weight

displayImages.caption: Quezon City, Philippines A teacher tries to persuade a sobbing student, clinging to an unidentified girl, to enter the classroom for his first day at the President Corazon C Aquino elementary school. More than 23 million pupils returned to school on Monday Photograph: Aaron Favila/AP
displayImages.altText: A teacher, tries to convince a crying grade school student, clinging to an unidentified girl, to enter the classroom as he attends his first day of school
displayImages.cleanCaption: Quezon City, Philippines A teacher tries to persuade a sobbing student, clinging to an unidentified girl, to enter the classroom for his first day at the President Corazon C Aquino elementary school. More than 23 million pupils returned to school on Monday

displayImages.caption: London, UK A sculpture entitled Children Playing Game by the late US artist Duane Hanson is displayed at the Serpentine Sackler gallery. Hanson’s lifelike pieces, portraying working-class Americans and overlooked members of society, have been united in the largest exhibition of his work in Britain since 1997 Photograph: Toby Melville/Reuters
displayImages.altText: A visitor walks past a sculpture entitled Children Playing Game by the late US artist Duane Hanson at the Serpentine Sackler Gallery
displayImages.cleanCaption: London, UK A sculpture entitled Children Playing Game by the late US artist Duane Hanson is displayed at the Serpentine Sackler gallery. Hanson’s lifelike pieces, portraying working-class Americans and overlooked members of society, have been united in the largest exhibition of his work in Britain since 1997

displayImages.caption: London, UK David Cameron plants flowers during a visit to a nursery. A new bill promises to increase the childcare allowance for working parents with a household income of less than £150,000. It is not clear how many hours they will have to work to qualify Photograph: Carl Court/Getty Images
displayImages.altText: David Cameron plants flowers with children during a visit to a children’s nursery
displayImages.cleanCaption: London, UK David Cameron plants flowers during a visit to a nursery. A new bill promises to increase the childcare allowance for working parents with a household income of less than £150,000. It is not clear how many hours they will have to work to qualify

displayImages.caption: Tavarua, Fiji Laura Enever of Australia posts a near-perfect 9.43 ride to win the first-round heat at the WSP Women’s Pro competition Photograph: Kirstin Scholtz/EPA
displayImages.altText: Laura Enever of Australia posting a near perfect 9.43 ride to win her Round 1 heat at the Fiji Womens Pro competition
displayImages.cleanCaption: Tavarua, Fiji Laura Enever of Australia posts a near-perfect 9.43 ride to win the first-round heat at the WSP Women’s Pro competition

displayImages.caption: Kathmandu, Nepal Girls perform during International Children’s Day celebrations. The country is slowly recovering from a series of devastating earthquakes and aftershocks Photograph: Sunil Sharma/Xinhua Press/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Children present a performance during a celebration of the International Children’s Day
displayImages.cleanCaption: Kathmandu, Nepal Girls perform during International Children’s Day celebrations. The country is slowly recovering from a series of devastating earthquakes and aftershocks

displayImages.caption: Shandong Province, China Fishermen in the Yantai. A three-month fishing ban on the southern Pearl river and a section of the Yangtze is under way in an effort to facilitate environmental restoration Photograph: Tang Ke/Xinhua Press/Corbis
displayImages.altText: Shandong Province, China Fishermen in their boats in Yantai as a 3-month fishing ban started
displayImages.cleanCaption: Shandong Province, China Fishermen in the Yantai. A three-month fishing ban on the southern Pearl river and a section of the Yangtze is under way in an effort to facilitate environmental restoration

displayImages.caption: Bangkok, Thailand A worshipper places a gold leaf on a giant Buddha statue for good luck at Royal Field as part of Wesaka Bucha. The celebrations mark the birth, enlightenment and death of the spiritual leader Photograph: Sakchai Lalit/AP
displayImages.altText: Bangkok, Thailand A Buddhist puts a gold leaf on a giant Buddha’s statue for good luck at Royal Field as part of Wesaka Bucha activities, marking the birth, enlightenment and death of Lord Buddha
displayImages.cleanCaption: Bangkok, Thailand A worshipper places a gold leaf on a giant Buddha statue for good luck at Royal Field as part of Wesaka Bucha. The celebrations mark the birth, enlightenment and death of the spiritual leader

displayImages.caption: Madrid, Spain The national rhythmic gymnastics team strike a pose during a training session in the runup to the European Games in Baku, Azerbaijan, this month Photograph: Emilio Naranjo/EPA
displayImages.altText: Madrid, Spain Spanish National Rhythmic Gymnastics team members pose during a training session of the team ahead the Baku 2015 European Games
displayImages.cleanCaption: Madrid, Spain The national rhythmic gymnastics team strike a pose during a training session in the runup to the European Games in Baku, Azerbaijan, this month

displayImages.caption: Havana, Cuba Actor Aimee Perez poses for a photo as she has her body painted to perform as part of the creation Mutación Forzada, or Forced Mutation, by Cuban Artist Alberto Lescay during the 12th Havana biennial Photograph: Alexandre Meneghini/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Havana, Cuba Actress Aimee Perez, 19, poses for a photo as she has her body painted to perform as part of the creation Mutacion Forzada, or Forced Mutation, by Cuban Artist Alberto Lescay during the 12th Havana Biennial

Burundi’s army chief says an attempted coup has failed and forces loyal to Pierre Nkurunziza are in control, a day after another general announced that he had sacked the president for seeking an unconstitutional third term in office Photograph: Goran Tomasevic/Reuters
displayImages.altText: Protesters, who are against President Pierre Nkurunziza’s decision to run for a third term, gesture in front of a burning barricade. The head of Burundi’s army said on Thursday that an attempted coup had failed and forces loyal to Nkurunziza were in control, a day after another general said he had sacked Nkurunziza for seeking an unconstitutional third term in office
displayImages.cleanCaption: Bujumbura, Burundi Anti-government protesters demonstrate near a burning barricade. In the early quarter of the twentieth century some of the world’s Egret species were endangered due to plume hunting for hat makers in Europe and the United States who used large numbers of Egret plumes for their hats. Fortunately Egret hunting was eventually outlawed and today numbers of Egrets are on the rise
